supportDesc.support: A memorial stone with three caitya arches on top, along with a scene of three persons in the lower panel with two attendants in the background (the one on the left carrying a chalice, and the one on the right carrying a fan).

layoutDesc.layout: The inscriptions are on the top left, top right, and bottom center of the main (lower) panel.

origin.origPlace: Sannati, on a slab set up in the temple of Bīrappa.

div.p: This edition is based on Sarma and Varaprasada Rao 1993.

To judge from the position of the labels, the larger male and female figures are Mugarakoṇha, the Bhojaka, and Kāmā, the Bhojikinī (a strange formation, seemingly a combination of Bhojinī and Bhojaka). They were probably a couple, and their aristocratic status is suggested by both their titles and the chalice and fan held in the background. The figure in the center, who is smaller, was called Kaṇhakoṭava and was the son of a scribe (lekhakaputra). He probably a close relation (perhaps a younger brother) of Mugarakoṇha.
The names evidently contain the word Kṛṣṇa (Mudgara-Kṛṣṇa and Kṛṣṇa-Kaustubha?).
The Bhojaka Mugarakoṇha, the Bhojikinī Kāmā, and the scribe’s son Kaṇhakoṭava.
